ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Some different paths of BME
A broad overview of BME fields and their applications
learned about fields in BME through career panels, alumni panels, guest prof. lectures, and presentations
Learned about career opportunities in BME.

I gained a lot of perspective as to what the Biomedical Engineering major is and what I can do with it. I used to be terrified of my job prospects with this major. However, the presentations and guest lecturers definitely helped in expanding my view of what BMErs can do.
I learned about a bunch of professors' origin stories, which made them seem more human and made me feel a bit more optimistic about my own future as a scientist.
Introduction to post-grad opportunities in BME and how you can use a BME degree
a survey of the BME field and the careers it offers
I learned about the various fields of biomedical engineering as well as opportunities in various career industries with a degree in biomedical engineering.
By taking this course, I learned the overall applications of biomedical engineering and learned how to build connections in the field.
knowledge about the biomedical engineering major

Through this course, I learned a lot about all the tracks in BME offered as well as an opportunity to speak with alumni. Through this course, I learned how to best contact and interview alumni as well.

Despite being interested in BME, I was not sure what BME careers really meant or looked like practically until I took this course. This introduced me to the many sectors and opportunities that exist in this field. The guest speakers were a highlight of the course.
The basics of the BME field
Overview of the field of Biomedical Engineering both from a research and industry perspective.
I learned a lot about the applications of biomedical engineering and how to pursue a career in the field.
The many different avenues one can take with a BME degree in research and industry settings
I got a good overview of the BME major.
I gained knowledge on what BME actually is and what a career in BME looks like.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I feel like this course could benefit by having a one-on-one sign up to talk with the professor about what you want to do during your time at Yale or career pathway options, and these meetings could be spread out throughout the semester. I think this would be much better for the student, rather than making them write a paper on why we want to do BME--because some students don't actually know if they want to do BME or not. As college is a time full of uncertainty, I think some more support would be more helpful, instead of assignments.
The strengths are that it's a low workload class that's meant to expose you to different areas of BME.
improvement: no quizzes or essays

I wish there was more opportunity to get to know our classmates in this class. I think it is very unique to have every student in your major and year in one class, but by the end of the semester I didn't know any more people than I knew on the first day. The guest lecturers were very informational, but I didn't think we needed to have so many of them as it began to feel repetitive after the first five or so. I would have appreciated more group projects throughout the semester (not just at the end) or time during class to work / have discussions with the professor and our peers.
Helped me gain perspective on BME. I loved interviewing a recent Yale BME graduate it helped me a lot.
This course was great as is and is definitely a good course for anyone toying with the idea of entering the major.
The speakers were great; I genuinely found myself feeling inspired at times, ready to leap into my own career.

It was very easy to be disengaged with the course. However, it was nice to have an introduction to post-grad opportunities so early in undergrad. Because of this course, I started looking for summer opportunities early and was able to commit to an internship before Thanksgiving.
well organized with a breadth of guest speakers
This course teaches the students a wide range of information about biomedical engineering and is reasonable in its assignments throughout the semester.

The course was fun in that it provided us with insight into the major and work done within the field. The workload was not bad, so I was able to spend more time looking at the options and discussing the major with others from the class as a result.
The one weakness I would comment on is that we did not receive any of our essay grades back before the end of the term which means that we did not receive feedback on where we stood grade-wise.
Strengths: guest speakers, engagement from professor, assignments
The fact that the course is very broad is both a strength and a weakness.

The course was very informative. It actually led me to draw conclusions about my interest in the field. It gives a great introduction into the possible careers, and I enjoyed hearing from actual biomedical engineers. The workload was also very low and allowed you to engage at the appropriate level for a 0.5 credit course. Professor Fan is also great and makes class enjoyable.
I liked it it could have more engagement and possible hands on activities

Strengths: low stress intro to what BME actually is, really helped me decide whether or not I wanted to major in BME

Weaknesses: class size was way too big for a seminar, if you decide not to major in BME then the material isnt super relevant since the class assumes everyone is a BME major

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are considering whether to take BME, this is a good class to understand the various aspects of BME.
Yes, especially if considering BME

I think it is helpful for deciding whether BME is something you want to pursue. It was very interesting to hear perspectives from people in varying fields of study / areas of employment that have all graduated from Yale with a BME degree. The workload is even less than what I would have expected for a half credit class, so definitely don't worry about being overwhelmed by the extra class. Professor Fan was always very nice and had extremely flexible deadlines for the few assignments we did have.
Yes! Required if BME major
Yes! Dr. Fan is a great professor, and he definitely makes his best effort to make the class fun and informative.
I took this course as a non-major. I don't regret it; it was a nice fifth class but don't pick it over something useful.
If you want a survey course in BME, sure. The workload is not bad at all.
yes, if considering BME this is a great course to help you decide if it is for you
I would recommend this course to another student because it provides good introductory information about biomedical engineering at Yale and beyond.
if you're thinking of taking BME, yes
Yes, this class is super important as it allows you to decide if BME is really for you.

I would recommend to BME students as it is a requirement, but it is also a good and relatively stress-free course that educates you about the different career and educational opportunities that you can follow after Yale.
Yes! Good to take to see if you want to major in BME
Yes, it is an interesting class that serves as an overview to biomedical engineering.
Yes. It gives you a nice introduction into biomedical engineering without being at all cumbersome in terms of workload.
Yes it was a very good introduction to BME and what the field entails
If you are an underclassman considering the BME major, I would recommend taking this to decide if you really really truly want to proceed with this major
Yes, because it really helped me decide whether I wanted to major in BME
